content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. The graph of the function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown on the interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 4 comma 6, close bracket " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> consists of two line segments and the portion of the graph of <math alttext="y equals, the square root of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x equals, g of x plus, the integral from negative 4 to x, of, g of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mi>x</mi></msubsup><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the value of <math alttext="f of 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. The graph of the function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown on the interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 4 comma 6, close bracket " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> consists of two line segments and the portion of the graph of <math alttext="y equals, the square root of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x equals, g of x plus, the integral from negative 4 to x, of, g of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mi>x</mi></msubsup><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the value of <math alttext="f of 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Show that <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point at <math alttext="x equals, negative 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded></math>. Use the Second Derivative Test to determine whether <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a local minimum or a local maximum at <math alttext="x equals, negative 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mpadded></mpadded></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(c) Find the value of <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 4 from the left, of, the fraction with numerator g of x, minus g of 4, and denominator x minus 4, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>4</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 2.2: Defining the Derivative of a Function and Using Derivative Notation

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
